properties.NAME: LAKE HELEN / CASSADAGA CEMETERY (1900)
properties.Descrip1: This cemetery serves the City of Lake Helen (founded 1888) and Cassadaga Southern Spiritualist Camp, the south’s oldest spiritualist community, founded in 1894.
properties.Descrip2: George Colby, the man responsible for establishing the camp which is still active, and Mary Stewart, also a Cassadaga pioneer are remembered here. Founding fathers of Lake Helen—A.H. Pelton and Samuel Currier are buried here.
properties.Descrip3: Founding fathers of Lake Helen—A.H. Pelton and Samuel Currier are buried here. This cemetery is noted for its brick mourning benches, intended for those grieving their loved ones, and later adapted in local folk tales to be called “devil’s chairs.

properties.NAME: JAMES ORMOND TOMB PARK
properties.Descrip1: In the early 1800s James Ormond Tomb Park was part of a 2,000-acre parcel of land that was developed into a cotton and indigo plantation called Damietta by Captain James Ormond I.
properties.Descrip2: Now this nine-acre section, which was donated to the Park Service in 1945, is the resting place of his son James Ormond II.

properties.NAME: MASONS COLORED CEMETERY/ST JOHNS (1899)
properties.Descrip1: Four cemeteries sit beneath the oak trees on Lake Louise. To the north of the Seville community cemetery where many founders of the northern part of Volusia County are laid to rest are three African American cemeteries.
properties.Descrip2: The largest, known as the Mason’s Colored Cemetery is on land purchased from the Masonic Lodge in 1899 for a church and burial ground.  The foundations of the St. John’s Baptist church remain in the center of the cemetery.
properties.Descrip3: The other, smaller cemeteries are known as Ward Chapel AME and AME Church cemetery.

properties.NAME: GETHSEMANE  CEMETERY
properties.Notes: AKA ORMOND BURIAL GROUNDS, ORMOND NEGRO CEMETERY

properties.NAME: ROBERTS CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: http://files.usgwarchives.net/fl/volusia/cemeteries/roberts.txt

properties.NAME: HARRIS CEMETERY (1918)
properties.Descrip1: This private cemetery is open to respectful visitors during daylight hours. One of the earliest burials in this family cemetery was Stephen Harris, a Civil War veteran who was born in Georgia in 1830.
properties.Descrip2: According to the military headstone he served in Co. "F" 7 Fla. Inf. CSA.

properties.NAME: EBENEZER LUTHERAN CEMETERY (1885)
properties.Descrip1: Land for this cemetery was donated by Nils Pierson in 1885 and is associated with Ebenezer Lutheran Church founded in 1884 through the Swedish Evangelical Lutheran Association of Pierson, Volusia, Florida.
properties.Descrip2: Headstones for Piersonville founding families of Swedish descent, the Andersens, Piersons, Eckman, Hagstrom, and others are located here.

properties.NAME: CLIFTON CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: Soon after arriving in Volusia County in 1852, Henry and Phoebe Clifton’s infant child died and was buried south of their house. The baby’s grave was the beginning of the Clifton Cemetery.
properties.Descrip2: Later, the Clifton brothers joined the Confederate army leaving their families at the homestead. Fear of Union raids forced those remaining to flee to Marion County, and upon their return, the original grave was overgrown and couldn’t be found.
properties.Descrip3: The general area was well known, and when the next family member died, a fence was put up around the new grave, insuring no more lost graves.

properties.NAME: LAKE DIAS CEMETERY (1887)
properties.Descrip1: Early settlers Tobias Blackwelder and his wife Dora (coming to the area in 1852) and other early settler families-- Clifton, Hunter and Tedder-- are buried on this high ground rising above Lake Dias.
properties.Descrip2: Here you can see many simple concrete markers decorated with shell, fragile and impermanent.

properties.NAME: DAYTONA MEMORIAL PARK
properties.Notes: ALSO KNOWN AS BELLEVUE MEMORIAL CEMETERY

properties.NAME: DAYTONA MEMORIAL PARK
properties.Notes: AKA CEDAR HILL CEMETERY, BELLEVUE CEMETERY

properties.NAME: LUNGREN CEMETERY
properties.Notes: AKA PIERSON CEMETERY / AKA EVERGREEN CEMETERY

properties.NAME: PURDOM CEMETERY (1879)
properties.Descrip1: Joseph Underhill, a Seminole War veteran who served from 1857-1858 and was stationed at Ft. Volusia is buried here, along with other Underhill family members, and early settlers: Minshews, Davis, Roberts, Purdom and others.
properties.Descrip2: The brick crypts in this cemetery are the earliest markers and are among only a few of this type monument found in Volusia cemeteries.

properties.NAME: MIDWAY METHODIST CHURCH CEMETERY (1880)
properties.Descrip1: The original Midway United Methodist Church was built on this site in 1872. It was so named to signify the midpoint of the Jacksonville-Tampa circuit at the time. A larger church was built in 1890 that was used until the 1960s.
properties.Descrip2: Visitors can visit this historic structure today at the Pioneer Settlement for the Creative Arts. Church members and Midway’s early pioneers are buried here-- McBride, Morrison, Barber, Reeves, Cade, Buckles and other families.

properties.NAME: JOHNSON CEMETERY
properties.Notes: AKA MOUNT OLIVE PRIMITIVE BAPTIST CEMETERY (1896)
properties.Descrip1: This small cemetery sits on high ground overlooking Johnson Lake. The Mt. Olive Primitive Baptist Church built in 1920 once stood at the front of the graveyard—it was demolished in 1965.
properties.Descrip2: The Daughtery family and others associated with the Spring Garden settlement rest here.

properties.NAME: BETHEL CEMETERY (1883)
properties.Descrip1: Bethel Methodist Episcopal Church stood on the west side of the cemetery from 1883 till about 1937 when it was destroyed by fire. Here you can find the Rev. James H. Chandler’s grave.
properties.Descrip2: Chandler, a Methodist minister, county judge, county treasurer, and signer of Florida Articles of Secession, died in 1888.

properties.NAME: PINEHURST CEMETERY (1886)
properties.Descrip1: This large cemetery is the final resting place for several Confederate soldiers, and early DeLeon Springs families—Broderick, McGinness, Hamilton, Lynch and others.

properties.NAME: GLENWOOD CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: This cemetery is associated with the Glenwood Presbyterian Church, established in 1886, still serving its congregation on Grand Avenue. Judge Issac Stone is buried there, as well as early settlers—Van Cleef, Bredow, Buell, Conrad and Sproul families.
properties.Descrip2: http://files.usgwarchives.net/fl/volusia/cemeteries/glenwood.txt

properties.NAME: OAKDALE CEMETERY (1882)
properties.Descrip1: This is one of the largest historic cemeteries in Volusia County with more than 15,000 grave sites. Established in 1882 and called Sylvan Park, the cemetery was expanded and renamed in 1892.
properties.Descrip2: The new owners, the Women’s City Improvement and Protection Association of DeLand, Florida, raised $200 to purchase the property for this town cemetery. It is the resting place for many of the town’s founding members and notable figures.

properties.NAME: UNION CEMETERY (1898)
properties.Descrip1: This African American burial ground was established by members of the Greater Union Baptist Church still active in DeLand. The earliest graves were unmarked or can no longer be found. The Wright family cemetery sits beside it to the east.
properties.Descrip2: This cemetery features several Mosiac Templar headstones. The Mosaic Templars of America was an African American fraternal organization founded in 1882 by two former slaves.
properties.Descrip3: The organization was established to provide important services such as burial and life insurance to the African-American community.
properties.Descrip4: Mosaic Templars' burial insurance policies covered funeral expenses for members, both men and women, who maintained monthly dues. By 1913, the burial insurance policy also included these Vermont marble markers.

properties.NAME: M E CHURCH CEMETERY
properties.Notes: EXTREMELY OVERGROWN, COULD NOT LOCATE HEADSTONES

properties.NAME: PREVATT SETTLEMENT CEMETERY
properties.Notes: AKA OLD CAMP AKA OLD WELLS

properties.NAME: BERESFORD CEMETERY (1872)
properties.Descrip1: This is one is one of the oldest formal rural cemeteries in Volusia County. Founding families of the of the Beresford community who began to settle here in 1870 are buried here—Kirk, Alexander, Hill, Lowrie, Sparkman, Stuart, Bracey, Wilcox and Douglas
properties.Descrip2: These settlers, Civil War veterans (Union and Confederate) operated steamboats, planted orange groves, packed and shipped citrus, ran a general store, built homes and raised families.  The Beresford Presbyterian Church once stood on this site.

properties.NAME: HOLLYWOOD CEMETERY (1875)
properties.Descrip1: On February 8 of 1875, a group of men from the new settlement of Orange City purchased this land from the state and dedicated this as cemetery for the growing town. In the same year, President Grant signed the Civil Rights Act of 1875 into law.
properties.Descrip2: This Act was a United States federal law enacted during the Reconstruction Era that stated all races and colors were “entitled to the full and equal enjoyment of the accommodations, advantages, facilities, and privileges of inns, public conveyances
properties.Descrip3: on land or water, theaters, and other places of public amusement.” However, by 1883 the Supreme Court decided the act was unconstitutional. To comply with the ruling, the cemetery promptly divided into equal halves for whites and blacks.
properties.Descrip4: The western five acres became Lincoln Cemetery, dedicated for the internment of the town’s African American population. Hollywood became the white cemetery.

properties.NAME: MISSIONARY METHODIST CHURCH CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: http://files.usgwarchives.net/fl/volusia/cemeteries/misbp.txt
properties.Descrip2: Cemetery Is Neglected and In Danger Of Being Lost.

properties.NAME: GARFIELD SETTLEMENT CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=cr&CRid=2292543&CScntry=4&CSst=11&CScnty=379&CSsr=21&

properties.NAME: OSTEEN CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: The earliest burials here are twin infant sons of M.F. and Annie Osteen. Later, in 1884 this land was deeded to John Sauls and the Trustees of Saulsville Cemetery.
properties.Descrip2: Pioneer families from this area called Osteensville and Saulsville—Sauls, Carpenter, Tate, Pell, Osteens, Ellis and others rest here. Hezekiah Ellis Osteen is buried here.
properties.Descrip3: He served as a private in the Florida Seminole War (1839), later settled first near Spring Garden before establishing his homestead and store, naming the settlement after himself. The act that created Volusia County called for an election in 1855,
properties.Descrip4: where he was first elected sheriff, assessor and collector. George and Adeline Sauls are also here. Their family came to the area in 1859, There is a memorial in the cemetery recognizing the Sauls’ community building activities.

properties.NAME: CLINTON FAMILY CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: The Clinton family homestead was located in a small former community called Ariel. Edward Clinton and his family came from Georgia and were among the earliest residents.
properties.Descrip2: He served as a Confederate soldier in the Civil War and died in 1922 at the age of 88. Kaye Viola Clinton (born 1875) married James Huskey (born 1871.) Both are buried here along with many descendants in this peaceful rural burial ground.

properties.NAME: BAPTIST CHURCH CEMETERY
properties.Notes: NOT ACCESSIBLE, NO BURIALS DUE TO WET CONDITIONS

properties.NAME: LINCOLN CEMETERY (1875)
properties.Descrip1: On February 8 of 1875, a group of men from the new settlement of Orange City purchased this land from the state and dedicated this as cemetery for the growing town. In the same year, President Grant signed the Civil Rights Act of 1875 into law.
properties.Descrip2: This Act was a United States federal law enacted during the Reconstruction Era that stated all races and colors were “entitled to the full and equal enjoyment of the accommodations, advantages, facilities, and privileges of inns, public conveyances
properties.Descrip3: on land or water, theaters, and other places of public amusement.” However, by 1883 the Supreme Court decided the act was unconstitutional. To comply with the ruling, the cemetery promptly divided into equal halves for whites and blacks.
properties.Descrip4: The western five acres became Lincoln Cemetery, dedicated for the internment of the town’s African American population. Hollywood became the white cemetery.

properties.NAME: ST JOHNS MISSIONARY CHURCH CEMETERY AKA SEVILLE CEMETERY
DELEON SPRINGS CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: Adjacent to Pinehurst is the Fairport African American Cemetery with many unmarked graves, and headstones impacted by the modern roadway.

properties.NAME: CEMETERY
properties.Notes: HEADSTONES BURIED WHEN PROPERTY SOLD-LOC UNK

properties.NAME: FISHER CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: This cemetery is located next to a barn on Rendy Rd. owned by Tom & Lorellel Friend who helped us locate the cemetery,

properties.NAME: CAUSEY FAMILY CEMETERY (1873)
properties.Descrip1: This cemetery is on private property but can easily be seen US 17. The Causey Settlement was made up of several brothers who arrived from Georgia in 1857. Thomas Erastus was accompanied by his wife, Ann C. and baby son, John Gibson.
properties.Descrip2: Their first home was a log cabin, which would later be considered the first home to have been erected within what was to become the city limits of Seville when it was incorporated in 1887.
properties.Descrip3: Erastus and Ann are believed to be buried with their descendants and other members of the extended family in this cemetery, although Erastus’s grave maker is no longer there.

properties.NAME: PONCE INLET GRAVESITE
properties.Descrip1: There are three graves located in the parking lot of the Sun Cruz Casino. They are roped off in a little island of the parking area. The location is Beach and Front Street in Ponce Inlet.

properties.NAME: ENTERPRISE EVERGREEN CEMETERY (1882)
properties.Descrip1: The earliest marked grave in this cemetery is 1882, belonging to W. D. Moore.
properties.Descrip2: This cemetery replaced older burial places in Enterprise, probably due to the yellow fever epidemic and the decision to further separate the cemetery from homesteads and businesses.
properties.Descrip3: Annie Bradley succumbed to this disease in 1888 and is buried here, along with the Edward Lochhead Turquand (1894) Rector of All Saints Episcopal Church.
properties.Descrip4: This cemetery is still in use and includes unmarked graves of African Americans

properties.NAME: OAKLYNN CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: http://files.usgwarchives.net/fl/volusia/cemeteries/oaklynn.txt

properties.NAME: FRIENDSHIP
properties.Descrip1: This Cemetery is located on Private Property on Taylor Road and is fenced by the land owner who gave me permission to survey the headstone inscriptions. There are only 2 headstones but here are sunken locations in line with the headstones
properties.Descrip2: indicating others are probably buried there. Sept. 30, 1998

properties.NAME: MOUNT ZION PRIMITIVE BAPTIST CEMETERY (1874)
properties.Descrip1: The focal point of this cemetery is the meeting house that was built in 1877.  This structure housed the congregation of Mt. Zion Primitive Baptist Church, the first organized church in Pierson, and also served as a schoolhouse.
properties.Descrip2: As was often the custom at the time, the churchyard was a gathering place for the community. One of the notable burials is Melvin Long, the inspiration for a character in The Yearling.

properties.NAME: CONE CEMETERY
properties.Descrip1: This burial site is in the middle of Pasco Cades fernery in Seville, Volusia County, Fla. and well protected and maintained by the Cade family. It was the homestead of Volusia County Sheriff William Aaron Cone and his wife Mary Hagan from Bulloch Co., Ga
